issue.body:
Fixes #32967.

Also fix incorrect defaults for `enforcementPercentage` fields.

body: Thanks for the bug report!  This should be fixed by #33069.

I'm afraid I have some bad news about this.  We've had some internal discussions and have realized that outlier detection was actually never intended to work with the pick_first LB policy, and we don't want to support it with pick_first.  There are several reasons for this:

- Outlier detection does not work with pick_first in grpc-java and grpc-go.  [gRFC A50](https://github.com/grpc/proposal/blob/master/A50-xds-outlier-detection.md) says that [if the subchannel is created with multiple addresses, the subchannel will be ignored for outlier detection](https://github.com/grpc/proposal/blob/master/A50-xds-outlier-detection.md#outlier-detection-behavior), which is the case when using pick_first in grpc-java or grpc-go.  That is not the case in C-core, but we don't want to support something in one language that we can't support in the others.
- While your particular use-case does make sense, there are other cases where it can cause problems.  For example, if pick_first has only one address, ejecting an address can cause unnecessary connection churn.
- More generally, we are planning to make some significant structural changes as part of the forthcoming design for supporting dualstack IPv4/IPv6 backends, and as part of that work, we are going to be modeling outlier detection as a health signal instead of a connectivity signal.  This will make it similar to what we support for client-side health checking (see [gRFC A17](https://github.com/grpc/proposal/blob/master/A17-client-side-health-checking.md)), which we [explicitly do not support with pick_first](https://github.com/grpc/proposal/blob/master/A17-client-side-health-checking.md#pick_first).  If we start supporting outlier detection with pick_first now, it will cause complications for this dualstack design.

So while I'm glad I fixed this crashing bug, I'm going to add a hack to explicitly disable outlier_detection from working with pick_first.  That way, no one will start depending on this and then get their code broken later when we implement the dualstack design.

For your particular use-case, I recommend that you consider using an LB policy other than pick_first, where outlier detection has more clearly defined semantics without the kind of problematic edge cases that it can cause with pick_first.

@ejona86 @dfawley

issue.title: [outlier detection] hack to prevent OD from working with pick_first
